CLUB PATRON SAINT﻿
Pope Paul VI﻿

CLUB PATRON
Archbishop Cyprian Kizito Lwanga﻿

widgetsright.data:
CLUB FOUNDER
Cardinal Emmanuel Nsubuga﻿

CLUB OBJECTIVES
  1. Provide oppotunities for recreation, games and sports, social intercourse and refreshment to members.
  2. To support and subscribe to any charitable Organization, public body or institution.

widgetsmiddle.data:
THE HISTORY OF NORMS AND TRADITIONS OF THE POPE PAUL VI SOCIAL CLUB LTD﻿

The club was started in 1978 by the then Archbishop of Kampala, the Late Emmanuel Cardinal Nsubuga. As early as 1978, the Cardinal had identified respectable people in society to lead the club. Some of them formed an interim Executive of the club. In March 1979, the first meeting of the club was convened by the Late B K Kiyimba who was then the Manager of Pope Paul Complex. During this meeting, Hon. Andrew Ben Ssengooba became the first Chairperson of the club. The first club constitution was prepared and passed by the then members. The pioneer members recruited new members by invitation. The application forms were collected from the Archbishop’s office..

The day the club was opened by the interim Executive, the Cardinal arrived earlier than many pioneer members. He immediately joined the members he found playing omweso (Buganda Chess). The Cardinal exhibited skills of playing this game and its associated jokes. As one of the jokes, the Cardinal challenged the members to produce a one-shilling coin which was rare at that time. He went ahead to offer two beers to whoever would produce the coin. Mr. Frank Mbalire (RIP) produced two coins instead of one. The Cardinal then doubled his offer and gave him four bottles of beer. As the club meeting was about to start, Mr. Mbalire shared the four beers with the people he was playing with. The Cardinal then commented that “this is the real purpose of the club, that sharing is the Christian way of saying I love you. For Jesus to be popular, he emphasized the need to help each other.” The Cardinal then gave all members who were present one bottle of beer each in appreciation of Mr. Mbalire’s act of sharing. This became the first norm of the club that when a member appreciates another, he/she gives ekita/bita. When the meeting started, the Chairman, Hon. Ssengooba requested the Cardinal to give his maiden speech as the First Patron of the club.

In his address, the Cardinal thanked Hon. Ssengooba for accepting to lead the club and also thanked the members who responded to the invitation. He emphasized the need to build the club on the foundation of love as Jesus loves everyone and died for all of us. He further advised members to keep in mind that this is a social club for respectable members of society. He added that human beings belong to one big family.

It was on this second day of the club that the Chairman’s table was put in place. This was to create a separate place where the Executive and dignitaries sit. The Chairman’s table has evolved to the current “State House” Village.

The second norm was created on the second day of the club meeting and it was about the Chairman’s table. Any member who was not an Executive or a dignitary and sat in the Chairman’s table area and Chairman’s Chair was fined (okutanzibwa). During that meeting, Mrs. Catherine Kiwanuka, the wife of the late politician, Joseph Jolly Joe Kiwanuka bought a bottle of whisky from the club counter and presented it to the Chairman as a sign of allegiance to the Chair. From then on, any member who offers a drink/kita presents it to the Chair who acknowledges the offer and asks the servers to distribute the drinks to the members (Ssentebe alangirira nti ekita kisaasaane) When a lot of drinks were offered and they were not consumed on that day, they were kept to be consumed the following day as “entandikwa”. These drinks were referred to as “mawolu”. In the case of spirits and wines, only one member was trusted to keep them, and that was Ssalongo Emmanuel Mumira. However, the spirits and wines left over these days remain in the custody of the club manager.

The Chairman used to receive many drink offers which made him appoint a distributor (omusenero). The first musenero was Mr. Vincent Bbaale Mugera (RIP) and his deputy was Mr. Livingstone Mukasa (RIP). From the bita, the Chairman, Executive and dignitaries used to take more than ordinary members. At times members used to over drink and those who misbehaved were asked to leave the club by the Executor (Mukajanga) who was appointed by the Chairman. The first Executors were Mr. Charles Kasozi Ddamba (RIP) and Mr. Noah Mbowa (RIP).

The Chairman also appointed a Solicitor General and a Deputy who were assigned the duties of receiving applications for new members, complaints, disciplinary actions and fines. The first members to be appointed were Mr. Joseph Balikkudembe (RIP) as the Solicitor General and H.E Edward Ssekandi as his Deputy.

Mr. George W. Kasibante was appointed by the Chairman as “Prince”. This was after members complained that Mr. Kasibante had a habit of speaking without permission/ interjecting speakers but he was never fined. The Chairman’s reply to the complaining members was that what Mr. Kasibante said usually made sense and as such he declared him a Prince. The petitioners were not happy with the Chairman’s ruling. Consequently, the Chairman appointed the Chief Petitioner, Owek. Mr. John Muganga as the club’s Bank Governor. The Chief Petitioner thanked the Chair for the appointment and he informed members that he had become “Munywannya” (4 tots of whisky because he had joined the Executive).

The club gained members and excitement and members introduced clans (bika) in the club. The first applicant was Matia Mukasa (RIP), who was the club’s first Auditor. He applied to be the Mamba Clan leader (Gabunga). His wife who was cheerful and smartly dressed was nicknamed Lady Gabunga. (lives in the US). The Ente clan selected Mr. William Ssenyondo as their clan leader (Katongole). The Mbogo clan which the Chairman, Hon. Ssengooba and the Deputy Solicitor General, H.E Edward Ssekandi belonged to, selected Hon. Evaristo Nyanzi (RIP) as their clan leader (Kayiira Gajuule). On appointment, Hon. Nyanzi threw a party and entertained members until morning. His wife, Aireda Nyanzi is still an active member of the club. As Bannansangwawo (the clans which Kabaka Kintu found in Buganda) were not happy seeing new clans getting space, members of the Ngonge clan selected Mr. John Muganga to lead them as their leader (Kisolo). He was sworn in by the Solicitor General. His wife, the princess of Bunyoro, gave an interesting speech about how her Babiito/Ngabi clan came in existence.

There are several instances where members offer bita. For example, whenever members travel outside the country, they are also required to share their experiences to the members of the club during the fellowship (okunyumya olugendo) and offer ebita. When new members are introduced to the club during the fellowship, it is a norm that they offer ebita to the members. They are several other instances when individuals/families offer bita to club members.

There were members who chose to drink from the counter and this place was named “Eggwagi. “The Eggwagi members selected Mr. John Nkwaju, the founder of Eggwagi, to be their leader. The Eggwagi members wanted to have a clan leader among themselves. Consequently, Mr. Nkwaju who belonged to the Mutima Clan became the Clan Leader (Kakeeto). Members of the Ngabi Clan selected Mr. George William Lubega (RIP) to be the clan leader (Nsamba). It was a big party as other tribes, e.g. Basoga and Banyoro who belong to the Ngabi clan joined the ceremony. Other clans have since acquired space (bibanja) and these include the Lugave whose leader is Ndugwa, - Prof. Joseph Mukiibi, the Nkima whose leader is Mugema;-Mr. Aloysious Ssali, the Ngeye, whose leader is Kasujja-Mr. Francis Katabalwa, the Mamba whose leader is Gabunga- Mr. Budde D Kigonya, the Butiiko clan whose leader is Ggunju-John Wagaba, Ffumbe whose leader is Walusimbi-Owek. John Baptist Walusimbi.

Recently, the club introduced villages (Ebyaalo) and these are Muyenga, and the Chair is Mr. Lawrence Lugwana, Kololo, the Chair is Mr. Peter Jjemba Kaggwa, Buruli, the Chair is Mr. Bruno Matovu, Masaka Village, the Chair is Mr. Paul Lule and State House, the Chair, is the Chairperson of the club, Prof. Maria Musoke.

Another norm is that members care for each other’s welfare by burying the departed members and their families which is accompanied by the club’s condolence message, and wreathe with organized transportation by the Executive, to and from the burial. This is accompanied by the “mataba” which is condolences taken to the bereaved family members after the burial. The members also visit the sick either at the hospital or at home to boost morale while keeping the club spirit alive.

Choosing leaders /Executive members to manage club affairs through the Annual General Meeting is another norm that is maintained to date.

The successful amendment of the Articles of Constitution by members to effectively manage club affairs is another norm.

Every candidate for admission as an Ordinary member shall be proposed and seconded by Ordinary members who shall have been members of the club for not less than two years. The proposer and seconder shall be responsible for inducting the applicant. Every application for membership shall be in writing on a form which should be handed to the Secretary. The Executive Committee reserves the right to admit members based on the different classification of members, with the application released from the waiting list book and placed on the notice board for a period of sixty days. The form is then removed and forwarded to by the Secretary to the Membership subcommittee for consideration. The candidate shall enjoy the privileges of a temporary member after his application having been endorsed by the Secretary. The Membership sub-committee shall decide on all application forms for admission and recommend to the Executive. The quorum for a meeting of the membership sub-committee shall be one half other total number thereof. The Membership sub-committee in the process of considering the application may interview the applicant, his/her proposer and seconder and may also take views from the club members regarding the suitability of the application. The Secretary shall notify the candicate who fails to be admitted the reasons for his/her failure, from the date of the communication, the candidate shall cease to enjoy the privileges of a Temporary member. Any candicate who fails to be admitted shall not be eligible for admission until after the the lapse of 6 months. The successful candidate shall become a member after being admitted by the Executive Committee, and paying the prescribed fees as applicable in a period not exceeding 2 months from the date of admission. Failure to pay the prescribed fees in the stated period, the applicant shall forfeit his/ her admission. The Secretary after the payment of the prescribed fees, according to rule 5.5.8(ii) enter the members’ name in the register, gives him a membership number and a copy of the Club Constitution (Memorandum and Articles of Association). The Membership subcommittee shall also be responsible for members’ discipline and welfare. The new member is officially welcomed to the club during the fellowship and he or she buys drinks/bitas for members.

The club has different categories of members as follows:

 Ordinary members that are entitled to all the privileges of the club.

Spouse member - If an ordinary member’s spouse is interested in becoming a member, he/she needs the spouse’s written consent in writing before he/she becomes a spouse member. The member however pays half the subscription fees, the ordinary member pays. However, this spouse member loses membership if he/she decides to remarry after he/she becomes a widow/widower and he/she has to then apply for ordinary membership.


Honorary members are any distinguished people who have rendered good service to the Club, or any paid official of the club, who may be admitted as an Honorary member, provided that person has been voted by two thirds majority of those present. He or she is exempted from all membership fees and subscriptions; however he or she is not be eligible to either vote or stand for any office.

Compassionate members have a previous clean record but due to prolonged illness or age is not being able to actively participate in the club activities for twelve months. He/she enjoys the rights and privileges of the club but shall be exempted from paying annual subscription or otherwise except of his/her guarantee contained in Clause 5 of the Memorandum of the Association of the club. Any person is eligible to become a Temporary member if he/she is in Uganda for less than one year.
